page.title: 04 Otley 1086-1985(cont)
page.content: The picture which emerges at the dawn of the "Early modern" era is a village of widely scattered farmsteads, set in broad wooded pastures, and with no clearly defined centre as such. The yeomen derived their living from cattle farming, particularly dairying, with cereal production (mainly wheat) as a sideline. This system of farming was already well established by the end of the fifteenth century, and continued with very little change until the Napoleonic wars swung the pendulum abruptly and, as it transpired, irrevocably, to the plough.
